summary: we engineered site-specific S1/S2 mutations (RSVR751/S in Fig. 1B) the WT S1/S2-encoding region was replaced with the codons (YSAS751/S) from a MERS-CoV–related bat CoV-HKU4 (Hong Kong University 4). WT and mutant MERS-CoVs produced comparable amounts of progeny viruses in vero81 and Huh7 cells. mutant virus titers were nearly 3 log10 less virus than those of the WT. average progeny virus yields from HAE were 104.4 for WT and mutant SSVR viruses. proteins were evaluated by detecting C-terminal epitopes on western blots. mutants were specifically compromised for transduction into lung-derived Calu3 cells (Fig. 2A) and HAE cells (Fig. 2B) trypsin processed the uncleaved fraction of WT S proteins into fragments at 95 kDa. ySAS S proteins were cleaved at an alternative more N-terminal cleavage site. ySAS pp transductions were not affected by trypsin. MERS-CoV depends on S1/S2 cleavage by proprotein convertases within 293T producer cells to efficiently infect lung-derived Calu3 target cells. preliminary Cleavage increases SARS S-Mediated Virus-Cell Entry. luciferase levels in kilodaltons were measured at 48-h posttransduction. error bars present SD from the mean (n = 4) S1/S2 cleavage facilitates the receptor-induced exposure of a second S2′ cleavage site. the mixed pps were treated with increasing concentrations of trypsin. similar experiments were carried out in parallel with YSAS pps. proteases cleaving S proteins early after virus binding to target cells include serine-class transmembrane proteins (TMPRs) and furin/proprotein convertases (24, 37, 38), whereas those cleaving S proteins later, after virus endocytosis, include cysteine-class cathepsins (26). early and late coV-cell entry can be distinguished by their sensitivities to serine- and cysteine-specific protease virus entry was quantified by measuring luciferase levels in infected cells at 48-h (A, C) or 18-h (B) posttransduction. Error bars present SD from the mean (n = 3). TTSP family TMPR serine 2 (TMPRSS2) in Huh7 cells. overexpressed TMPRSS2 overexpression made all MERS pp transductions slightly sensitive to camostat. overexpressed TMPRSS2 overexpression made all MERS pp transductions completely resistant to E64d. Caco2 cells were incubated with protease inhibitors (100 M camostat, 50 M PCI, 10 M E64d) or with pp-lacking S proteins (Bald). cells were then transduced with WT or S1/S2 mutant (YSAS or SSVR) MERS pps. late-acting proteases in Calu3 cells accounted for virus resistance. transduced cells were highly sensitized to uncleaved MERS pp entry. similar augmentation of uncleaved MERS transduction was achieved by exposing cell-bound MERS pps to purified human cathepsin L. we engineered site-specific S1/S2 mutations (RSVR751/S) to evaluate the consequences of S proteolytic cleavage on virus infection. the WT S1/S2 region was replaced with the codons (YSAS751/S) from a MERS-CoV–related bat CoV-HKU4. mutants produced 4 log10 less viral mRNA than WT. mutants produced comparable amounts of progeny viruses in Vero81 and Huh7 cells. in Calu3 cells, mutant virus titers were nearly 3 log10 less virus than the WT. pps express firefly luciferase (Fluc), with Fluc levels providing quantitative measurements of virus-cell entry. the pps were pelleted, and particle-associated S proteins were evaluated by detecting C-terminal epitopes on western blots. MERS pps were prepared in serum-free 293T media (SFM) and incubated with trypsin before transduction. trypsin processed the uncleaved fraction of WT S proteins into fragments at 95 kDa. ySAS S proteins were cleaved at an alternative more N-terminal cleavage site. these pps were concentrated, and pp-associated S proteins were evaluated. those secreted from PCI-treated cells contained primarily uncleaved S proteins and were compromised for Calu3 transduction. preliminary Cleavage increases SARS S-Mediated Virus-Cell Entry. kilodaltons were incubated with trypsin pretreated pps. luciferase levels were measured at 48-h posttransduction. we hypothesized that the MERS-CoV S proteins respond to receptor binding by changing conformation. trypsin uniquely generated a stable 72-kDa fragment (Fig. 4A) however, in the presence of DPP4, trypsin uniquely generated a stable 72-kDa fragment (Fig. 4A) these findings suggest specific biologically meaningful cleavage sites are exposed in response to receptor binding. proteases cleaving S proteins early after virus binding to target cells include serine-class transmembrane proteins (TMPRs) and furin/proprotein convertases (24, 37, 38), whereas those cleaving S proteins later, after virus endocytosis, include cysteine-class cathepsins (26). early and late coV-cell entry can be distinguished by their sensitivities to serine- and cysteine-specific protease MERS pp transductions into Caco2 and Vero81 cells were also sensitive to inhibitors of later-acting proteases. three HAE cultures were incubated with indicated protease inhibitors. three HAE cultures were incubated with indicated protease inhibitors. mERS or VSV pps were differentially sensitive to protease inhibitors. we overexpressed the TTSP family TMPR serine 2 (TMPRSS2) in Huh7 cells. overexpressed TMPRSS2 overexpression increased Fluc accumulation. uncleaved MERS viruses require late proteases and do not infect Calu3 cells. we inferred that Calu3 cells are deplete in endosomal cathepsins. the inference was validated by measuring protease-encoding transcripts by quantitative RT-PCR. TMPRSS2, furin, cathepsin L, cathepsin B and hypoxanthine phosphoribosyltransferase (HPRT) mRNA levels were measured in Huh7 cell extracts. cells were transduced with lentiviral vectors encoding human cathepsin L or GFP. a proteolytic cascade can be viewed in the context of a proteolytic cascade that includes at least two cleavages in S proteins, first at S1/S2 then at S2′. for some variant forms of MERS-CoV, the cascade begins when viruses bind target cells, and then ends when a sufficient number of adjacent S proteins are triggered for fusion activation. uncleaved viruses bypassed early proteases and required late proteases. uncleaved mutants were able to infect the more cathepsin protease-enriched Huh7 and Vero81 cells. SSVR mutants are cleaved by extracellular proteases, making their infection resemble that of WT viruses at the point of entry into some HAE cells. the precleaved viruses are presumably processed to fusion-ready S2′ products by early cell-surface serine proteases. the recent 4A resolution structures of murine CoV (MHV) and human CoV (HKU-1) S proteins depict uncleaved ectodomain trimers, without ligation to receptors (16, 17) the current structures do suggest that receptor binding locks relatively dynamic S proteins into conformations that expose cleavage sites to host proteases. the affinity of SARS-CoV S with its receptor angiotensin converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) is 10- to 20-fold higher than that of MERS-CoV S with its receptor DPP4 (47, 48). this finding contrasts with the SARS-CoV epidemics of 2003–2004, where adaptive changes increased binding affinities to ACE2 (50). preliminary S1/S2 proteolysis gives infecting viruses the facility to use TMPRSS2 and other early-acting proteases. preliminary S cleavages may also contribute to the tissue tropism and pathogenesis of feline and murine coVs. MERS pps and DPP4 pps were incubated in 1:5 M ratios, digested with graded doses of trypsin, and S fragments visualized by Western blotting. GGACACTTCGCACTGAACTAGGGGTCAG 3′ M13_pUC F 5′ GTGAGCGGATAACAATTTCACACAGG 3′ Recombinant MERS-CoV Production and Infection. mutant MERS-CoVs were generated from bacterial artificial chromosomes and infected into vero81, Huh7, and Calu3 cells or HAE cultures. pseudoparticles were transduced into vero81, Primers for generating S1/S2 mutant authentic MERS-CoV Primer name Primer sequences MERS YSAS F 5′ CTCACACCTTCCAGTGTGCGCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCT TGTGAG 3′ 10443pBAC-F5 F 5′ ACGTTCATTACCTGACCATACCCGAG 3′ M13_pUC F 5′ CCTGTGTGTGAAATTTATCCGCTCAC 3′ M13_pUC F 5′ GTGAGCGGATAACAATTTCACACAGG 3′ Table S3. Huh7 cells were maintained in DMEM supplemented with 10% FBS, 10 mM Hepes, 0.1 mM nonessential amino acids, and 100 g/mL streptomycin. cell culture materials and reagents were obtained from Corning and HyClone, unless otherwise noted. pUC-MERS-1 fragments were digested with SwaI and PacI. pBAC-MERS-1 fragments were used to replace corresponding SwaI-PacI in pBAC-MERS. stock viruses were obtained after one cycle of amplification in vero81 cells. infectious viruses in cell extracts or the apical washes of infected HAE cultures were titrated by plaque assay in vero81 cells. DNA encoding codon-optimized MERS-CoV EMC/2012 S was purchased from GenScript. gen primers listed in Table S3 and PCR fragments were assembled using In-Fusion HD (Clontech) all constructs were confirmed by Sanger sequencing. Plasmids encoding hDPP4 and HCoV-229E S were purchased from OriGene. cell-free supernatants containing the pps were collected at 48-h posttransfection. transfected cells were incubated in SFM containing 50 M PCI (EMD Millipore) from 6-h posttransfection until harvest. pps were secreted into SFM, filtered, and stored as described above. HEK293T cells were transfected with lentiviral vectors encoding cathepsin L. cells were transfected with plasmids encoding MERS-CoV S, VSV G, or empty vector. cell-free supernatants were collected for 2472 h posttransduction. MERS pps prepared in SFM were incubated with cells for 1 h at 4 °C. triedpsin was inactivated with 100 g/mL soybean trypsin inhibitor (STI; Sigma-Aldrich) for 5 min at room temperature. Pelleted pps and infected cell lysates were mixed with SDS solubilizer. samples were heated at 95 °C for 5 min, separated in 10% (wt/vol) polyacrylamide-SDS gels. membranes were then probed with horseradish peroxidase-conjugated goat anti-mouse IgG (Perkin-Elmer), incubated with ECL substrate. HEK293T cells were maintained in 293T media. DMEM supplemented with 10% FBS, 10 mM Hepes, 100 mM sodium pyruvate, 0.1 mM nonessential amino acids. cell inserts were placed in 24-well plastic cell culture plates (Costar) twenty-four hours after seeding, the mucosal medium was removed and the cells were allowed to grow at the air-liquid interface. mutations in the S gene of pBAC-MERS were PCR-amplified. total RNA was isolated by Direct-zol RNA MiniPrep (Zymo Research) at 5h postinfection, cells were rinsed, homogenized in TRIzol. real-time PCR was performed to quantify mRNA expression levels of subgenomic nucleocapsid (N) and HPRT using primers listed in table S2 and Power SYBR Green PCR master mix. Primers for real-time PCR Target mRNA Primer name Primer sequences MERS-CoV N MERS-Leader 5′ CTCGTTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCT DNA encoding codon-optimized MERS-CoV EMC/2012 S was purchased from GenScript. pcDNA3.1-MERS S-C9 was PCR-amplified with mutagenic primers listed in Table S3. plasmid DNAs were incubated with polyethylenimine (PEI; Polysciences), at 1:3 DNA:PEI ratios, in Opti-MEM (Life Technologies) for 15 min at room temperature, then added dropwise to adherent cells (2 g DNA per 106 cells) transfected cells were incubated in SFM containing 50 M PCI (EMD Millipore) from 6-h posttransfection until harvest. cell-free supernatants containing pps were collected at 48-h posttransfection. cells were transfected with plasmids encoding MERS-CoV S, VSV G, or empty vector. cells were dissolved into cell culture lysis buffer. s in the supernatants were pelleted by centrifugation at 10,000 g for 1018 h. cells were lysed and luciferase levels quantified as a measure of VSV pp entry. target cells used for transduction were exposed to 100 M camostat, 50 M PCI, or 10 M E64d from 1 h before to 1 h after pp inoculations. MERS pps were pelleted through 20% (wt/vol) sucrose in HNE (20 mM Hepes, 100 mM NaCl, 1 mM EDTA) by centrifugation at 80,000 g for 2 h at 4 °C. infected cells were lysed in nonidet P-40 lysis buffer. total RNA (500 ng) was used for cDNA synthesis using the RNeasy Mini Kit (Qiagen) real-time PCR was performed to quantify mRNA expression levels of DPP4, TMPRSS2, furin, cathepsin L, cathepsin B, and HPRT.
